row.entry: These rules permit the court to give directions concerning the conduct of trials and set out the usual order of evidence and addresses by the parties. They also contain specific provisions relating to maintaining a record of the trial and the judgment.

entry.emph: Dismissal of proceedings and giving of judgment — Rules 29.8–29.10

row.entry: These rules contain provisions relating to applications, by either the plaintiff or the defendant, for the dismissal of the proceedings.

entry.emph: Refusal to hear proceedings where fees unpaid — Rule 29.14

row.entry: This rule gives the court a discretion to refuse to proceed with the hearing of proceedings where relevant fees are unpaid.

This Part applies to all courts in Schedule 1 of the CP Act except in relation to proceedings in the Local Court, Small Claims Division: see r 1.5 and Sch 1. Rule 29 applies to the criminal proceedings in the Third Schedule to the Supreme Court Act and to Div 2 of Pt 75 of the SCR (summary jurisdiction): see SCR Pt 75 r 3.

The Part is substantially based on the former SCR Part 34, DCR Part 26 and LCR Part 21. The differences in the wording of the present rules are principally matters of expression rather than substance. Detailed permissible directions previously set out in the former Supreme Court rule have been reproduced in CPA s 62(2) . An application for judgment for want of evidence (see r 29.10) no longer involves an automatic election not to adduce evidence.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 29.1] r 29.1 Beginning and opposite parties (cf SCR Part 34, rule 1; DCR Part 26, rule 1A; LCR Part 21, rule 1A)

leg:heading.title: Beginning and opposite parties (cf SCR Part 34, rule 1; DCR Part 26, rule 1A; LCR Part 21, rule 1A)

p.text: Subject to any directions given by the court, for the purposes of this Part:
if the burden of proof on any issue lies on the plaintiff, the plaintiff is to be the beginning party and the defendant the opposite party, and
if the burden of proof on all the issues lies on the defendant, the defendant is to be the beginning party and the plaintiff the opposite party.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 29.2] r 29.2 Applications and requisitions for juries in proceedings other than defamation proceedings

leg:heading.title: Applications and requisitions for juries in proceedings other than defamation proceedings

p.text: This rule applies to proceedings other than defamation proceedings.
An application in proceedings to which this rule applies for the proceedings to be tried by jury must be made by notice of motion.

For the purposes of section 85 of the Supreme Court Act 1970 and section 76A of the District Court Act 1973, a requisition for a jury in proceedings to which this rule applies must be filed at the same time as the notice of motion referred to in subrule (2) is filed.
Unless the court otherwise orders, a notice of motion under subrule (2) must be filed:
if the notice is filed by the plaintiff:
within 56 days after service on the defendant of the statement of claim, or
if a defence is served on the plaintiff within that period, within 28 days after service of the defence on the plaintiff, or
if the notice is filed by the defendant:
within 28 days after service on the defendant of the statement of claim, or
if, pursuant to rule 14.3 , the court directs some other date for the filing of a defence, within 28 days after the date fixed by the court’s direction.
[r 29.2 subst Act 42 of 2011 Sch 1, effective 11 March 2011]
The approved form is Form 23B : Requisition for Trial by Jury.

Late service of a requisition for a jury on the plaintiff’s solicitor is not fatal to a trial proceeding by jury and time for service may be extended: Dubbo Stock & Station Agents Pty Ltd v Laws [2004] NSWCA 336; BC200406213 at [32], [34] and [35] . An expedited hearing and need for case management of the specific case may provide a sufficient specific reason to exercise the discretion to dispense with a jury: Dubbo Stock & Station Agents Pty Ltd v Laws , above, at [15]–[17], [34]–[35].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 29.2A] r 29.2A Elections for juries in defamation proceedings

leg:heading.title: Elections for juries in defamation proceedings

p.text: An election under section 21 of the Defamation Act 2005 for defamation proceedings to be tried by jury must be made by filing a notice of election for a jury trial and serving the notice on each other active party in the proceedings.

Section 21(2)(b) of the Defamation Act 2005 requires an election to be accompanied by the fee prescribed by the regulations under the Civil Procedure Act 2005 for the requisition of a jury in the court concerned.
A party may file and serve a notice of election for a jury trial only if:
the party has served a notice of intention to file the notice of election on each other active party before a date has been fixed for the hearing of the defamation proceedings, and
a notice of motion has not been filed under subrule (4) or, if such a notice of motion has been filed and served, the court has refused to make the order sought in the notice of motion.

A party who serves a notice of intention to file a notice of election for a jury trial must, before a date has been fixed for the hearing of the defamation proceedings, inform the court that the notice of intention has been served.

A party on whom a notice of intention to file a notice of election for a jury trial is served may, within 21 days of being served with the notice, file a notice of motion seeking an order under section 21 of the Defamation Act 2005 that the proceedings not be tried by jury.
If a notice of motion is filed under subrule (4) , a date may not be fixed for the hearing of the defamation proceedings until the court has disposed of the motion.
Without limiting subrule (2) , a notice of election for a jury trial may not be filed or served if:
the court makes an order under section 21 of the Defamation Act 2005 (whether or not of its own motion) that the defamation proceedings not be tried by jury, or
a date has been fixed for the hearing of the defamation proceedings.
[r 29.2A insrt Act 42 of 2011 Sch 1, effective 11 March 2011]
The approved form is Form 23A: Notice of Intention to Elect Trial by Jury in Defamation Proceedings.
Legislation cited in [29.2A.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 s 22, s 34, s 35, s 21.

Either party to defamation proceedings may elect to have liability, but not damages, issues heard by a jury — unless the court otherwise orders (eg where the trial requires a prolonged examination of records or involves any technical, scientific or other issues that cannot conveniently be considered and resolved by a jury): Defamation Act 2005 s 21 ; see also Ange v Fairfax Media Publications Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 1383; BC201009366 (defendant’s jury election — likelihood of extensive evidence, including offensive pornographic matter — jury not dispensed with). As to whether parties to proceedings commenced before the enactment of the section can so elect see Zollner Limited v Municipal Council of Sydney (1917) 17 SR (NSW) 164; 34 WN (NSW) 65 . The Defamation Act 2005 reserves determination of damages to the trial judge: s 22 . The damages must have an appropriate and rational relationship between the harm sustained by the plaintiff and quantum ( s 34 ) and are the subject of statutory regulation: s 35 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 29.3] r 29.3 Time and place of trial (cf SCR Part 34, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Time and place of trial (cf SCR Part 34, rule 4)

p.text: The court may make such order as it thinks fit for fixing the time and place of trial.

Normally it is convenient to try proceedings in the locality where the cause of action arose and where the majority of witnesses are resident. See Lehtonen v Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd [1963] NSWR 323 ; Kings Cross Whisper Pty Ltd v O'Neil [1968] 2 NSWR 289 . This proposition has sometimes been described as a general rule: O'Donoghue v Oliphant [1901] AC 315; (1901) 18 WN (NSW) 177 ; Egan v Barrier Branch of the Amalgamated Miners' Assn of Broken Hill (1917) 17 SR (NSW) 243; 34 WN (NSW) 13 . Some cases take the view that the plaintiff has the right to nominate the place of trial and in the absence of injustice or a manifest preponderance of convenience the venue should not be changed: Ryan v Harrison [1957] VR 210; [1957] ALR 572 ; Mahne v Schmidt (1889) 15 VLR 364; Lehtonen v Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd [1963] NSWR 323 (great inconvenience or injustice). However, the correct position is that the court's discretion is not confined by any particular formula: "The test is, where can the case be conducted or continued most suitably, bearing in mind the interests of all the parties, the ends of justice in the determination of the issues between them and the most efficient administration of the court? It cannot and should not … be defined more closely or precisely": National Mutual Holdings Pty Ltd v Sentry Corp (1988) 19 FCR 155; 83 ALR 434 . The fact that a view may be needed may be sufficient in a jury trial to indicate that the balance of convenience favours the venue proposed by the defendant: Budge v Britten (1902) 19 WN (NSW) 240. Where the trial is before a judge alone the need to have a view will ordinarily carry little weight. Particularly is this so where a lengthy trial is likely. However, in such a case it may be appropriate to take into account the respective hardships which would be inflicted upon the respective litigants by prolonged absences from their usual residences and places of work: Byrne and Davidson Engineering Pty Ltd v PMC Engineering Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, CL 11418/80, 2 October 1980, unreported, BC8000052).
Legislation cited in [29.3.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 66.
The power to adjourn proceedings is discussed in the notes to CPA s 66 .

What have usually been considered as proper grounds for a change of venue are the residence of the parties and their witnesses: Wilson v Syme (1880) 6 VLR 200; Australian Joint Stock Bank Ltd v Hockey (1903) 20 WN (NSW) 32 ; Permewan Wright & Co Ltd v Pearce (1903) 20 WN (NSW) 202; Churchill v Colliman (1906) 22 WN (NSW) 218; expense: Leversha v Wrangham (1889) 15 VLR 363 ; O'Brien v Scott (1900) 6 ALR (CN) 45; prejudice or the possibility of not having a fair trial: Kings Cross Whisper Pty Ltd v O'Neil [1968] 2 NSWR 289; R v Cattell [1968] 1 NSWR 156; Cording v Trembath [1921] VLR 163 (apprehended partiality of local jury panel); Mowle v Elliott (1937) 54 WN (NSW) 104 ; Hennessy v Badgery (1884) 1 WN (NSW) 34; Ryan v Harrison [1957] VR 210; [1957] ALR 572 ; Rundle v Bell (1963) 80 WN (NSW) 563 ; delay and generally the balance of convenience having regard to all considerations: Parnell v McLaughlin Ltd [1919] St R Qd 145 ; Budge v Britten (1902) 19 WN (NSW) 240; St Edmundsbury and Ipswich Diocesan Board of Finance v Clark [1973] Ch 323; [1973] 2 All ER 1155 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 29.4] r 29.4 Trial to deal with all questions and issues (cf SCR Part 33, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Trial to deal with all questions and issues (cf SCR Part 33, rule 4)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, proceedings are to be listed for trial generally, that is, for hearing of all questions and issues arising on every claim for relief in the proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 29.5] r 29.5 Conduct of trials generally (cf SCR Part 34, rule 6(1))

leg:heading.title: Conduct of trials generally (cf SCR Part 34, rule 6(1))

p.text: The court may give directions as to the order of evidence and addresses and generally as to the conduct of the trial.

level.toc-caption: [29.5.5] Explanatory note and cross references — directions powers

p.text: Legislation cited in [29.5.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 61, 62.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 31, 2.1, 2.3, r 29.6.

heading.title: Explanatory note and cross references — directions powers

p.text: The present rule complements the directions powers in CPA ss 61 and 62 and UCPR rr 2.1 and 2.3 . The notes to those rules discuss general issues relevant to the exercise of the directions power. The notes to UCPR r 29.6 deal with specific matters related to the ordinary procedure for the conduct of hearings. The following notes to the present rule cover a range of matters including admissibility of evidence, the usual practice in relation to evidence in chief and cross-examination and the calling of witnesses. More specific topics, such as the use of witness statements and expert evidence, are dealt with in the notes to Pt 31 .

Books of accounts kept according to an established system in organised business are receivable in evidence as proof of the financial progress or the result of business operations conducted on a large scale. When the books are produced, or their production is not insisted on, an accountant who has examined them may state their general effect: Potts v Miller (1940) 64 CLR 282 at 303; 14 ALJR 341 ; Re Montecatini's Patent (1973) 47 ALJR 161 at 169 ; Re Action Waste Collections Pty Ltd (in liq); Crawford v O'Brien [1981] VR 691 at 704; (1981) 38 ALR 199 at 214 .

Where the matter is such that ordinary persons are unlikely to have sufficient knowledge to give meaningful evidence expert evidence is admissible: Clark v Ryan (1960) 103 CLR 486; [1960] ALR 524 . The expert may express opinions even though ultimately the matter is one for the court: Commissioner for Govt Transport v Adamcik (1961) 106 CLR 292; [1961] ALR 892 . To be admissible the witness's alleged expertise must relate to a field specialised knowledge: ss 76–80 of the Evidence Act 1995; Milirrpum v Nabalco Pty Ltd (1971) 17 FLR 141 at 160 ; Appleby v Pursell [1973] 2 NSWLR 879 (evidence as to the meaning of technical terms); Subbotovsky v Waung [1968] 3 NSWR 499; (1968) 89 WN (Pt 2) (NSW) 166 (evidence of foreign law); Re Montecatini's Patent (1973) 47 ALJR 161 (accountancy); R v Gilmore [1977] 2 NSWLR 935 (spectrographic voice analysis). It is no longer a basis for objection to expert or opinion evidence that the matter is common knowledge or that it is a matter for the opinion of the court: s 80 of the Evidence Act 1995; contrast Clark v Ryan (1960) 103 CLR 486; [1960] ALR 524 . As to admissibility of reputable journals referred to in expert evidence, see H v Schering Chemicals Ltd [1983] 1 All ER 849; [1983] 1 WLR 143 . A more detailed understanding of the principles relating to expert evidence can be obtained from: Doyle, “Admissibility of Opinion Evidence” (1987) 61 ALJ 688; Von Doussa, “Difficulties of Assessing Expert Evidence” (1987) 61 ALJ 615; Gillies, “Opinion Evidence” (1986) 60 ALJ 597; I Freckleton and H Selby, Expert Evidence, Law Book Co, Sydney, 1993. These references should be considered having regard to ss 76–80 of the Evidence Act 1995. As to admissibility of an expert’s report see [31.24.5] .

Except in the case of the law of other Australian States, to which s 118 of the Constitution and s 143 of the Evidence Act 1995 apply, the law of a foreign country is a fact which must be pleaded (see [14.14.20] ) and proved by appropriate evidence: Subbotovsky v Waung [1968] 3 NSWR 499; (1968) 89 WN (Pt 2) (NSW) 166 ; Neilson v Overseas Projects Corporation of Victoria Ltd (2005) 223 CLR 331; 221 ALR 213; [2005] HCA 54; BC200507308 at [115] per Gummow and Hayne JJ, [185] per Kirby J, [249] per Callinan J, [261] per Heydon J. Sections 174–176 of the Evidence Act 1995 allow some aspects of foreign law to be proved by the production of official publications of legislation, treaties and law reports. As well, evidence may be given by an appropriately qualified person. In order for that kind of evidence of foreign law to be admissible, the witness must show “specialised knowledge” in accordance with s 79 of the Evidence Act. Often this would require that the witness either be legally qualified: Baron de Bodes' case (1845) 8 QB 208 ; Re Duke of Wellington [1947] Ch 506 at 514 ; or hold some office or official position in the relevant country which requires a knowledge of its law: Van Der Donckt v Thellusson (1849) 8 CB 812; 137 ER 727 (CP); cf Director Winters Transport v Duplante Canada Ltd (1961) 32 DLR (2d) 268. When there is no, or incomplete, evidence of foreign law, the presumption is that the foreign law is the same as the law of the forum: Neilson v Overseas Projects Corporation of Victoria Ltd , above, at [115], [116], [125] per Gummow and Hayne JJ, [249] per Callinan J, [261] per Heydon J, cf [193]ff per Kirby J. In some cases it may be appropriate for the parties to consider consenting to the trial judge forming his or her own view as to the content of foreign law. Thus in United States Surgical Corp v Hospital Products International Pty Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 766 McLelland J, where the foreign law in question was that of New York, the parties agreed “that in determining any question as to the law of any party of the United States of America the court (and any appellate court) (a) may, if and to such extent as it thinks fit, take judicial notice of the law, (b) may consider, in addition to the evidence adduced, any reported case, text book or journal article which appears to the court to be relevant, whether or not admissible or in evidence, or referred to in evidence”. This agreement was based upon r 44.1 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure (US).

It is sometimes said that once evidence is admitted it is admitted for all purposes, see, for example, Walker v Walker (1937) 57 CLR 630; 11 ALJR 201; Stunzi Ltd v House of Youth Pty Ltd (1959) 60 SR (NSW) 220; McLennan v Taylor (1966) 85 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 525 . However, the true rule may well be that evidence tendered if properly admissible is only evidence on the issue on which it was tendered, but that inadmissible evidence, admitted without objection, may be used for whatever rational persuasive power it has: Jones v Sutherland Shire Council [1979] 2 NSWLR 206 at 216–19 and see Electronic Rentals Pty Ltd v Anderson (1971) 124 CLR 27 ; Hughes v National Trustees Executors & Agency Co of Australasia Ltd (1979) 143 CLR 134; 23 ALR 321 . If evidence is admissible only for a particular limited purpose, and is not otherwise admissible for any other purpose, it ought not be used for any basis other than that which justified its admission: B v R (1992) 175 CLR 599; 110 ALR 432 at 437 ; Maxwell v DPP [1935] AC 309 at 321 . The judge has the role of determining which evidence is admissible and of ensuring that evidence is only used for the purposes for which it is legally admissible: Hughes v National Trustees Executors & Agency Co of Australasia Ltd (1979) 143 CLR 134; 23 ALR 321 ; Jones v Sutherland Shire Council [1979] 2 NSWLR 206 ; McLennan v Taylor (1966) 85 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 525 at 540 ; Ritz Hotel Ltd v Charles of the Ritz Ltd (1988) 88 ALR 217 (implied waiver of hearsay objections). That responsibility may permit, but not necessarily require: see Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Vines (2003) 48 ACSR 282; [2003] NSWSC 995; BC200306528 ; formal limitations on the use of evidence under s 136 of the Evidence Act 1995. There is also a discussion of the subject in “The status of hearsay and other evidence admitted without objection” (1978) 11 MULR 408 which, although primarily concerned with the criminal law, also considers the position in relation to civil trials. The position of hearsay evidence is now governed by s 60 of the Evidence Act 1995 — which permits the hearsay evidence to be used for the purpose of proving a fact asserted — subject to the exercise of the discretion in s 136 of that Act.

Objections to admissibility should be dealt with in the absence of the jury if the judge considers that discussion of the question of admissibility may unfairly prejudice the parties: Demirok v R (1977) 137 CLR 20 at 31; 14 ALR 199 . In the absence of the risk of such prejudice the jury ought to be present: Albrighton v Royal Prince Alfred Hospital [1980] 2 NSWLR 542 at 566 . If evidence given on the voir dire is relevant to matters in issue it may be given subsequently in the trial: Basto v R (1954) 91 CLR 628 at 639; 28 ALJR 519 . In non-jury matters it may also be appropriate to admit evidence either subject to relevance or subject to admissibility: Dubbo Base Hospital v Jones [1979] 1 NSWLR 225 at 227 ; and if the evidence subsequently proves to be inadmissible it ought to be struck out: Horne v Miln (1881) 7 VLR (L) 296 at 300 ; Evidence Act 1995 s 57.

A tape recording may be admitted into evidence provided it be established that the recording has been reliably made, that there has been no subsequent interference with the recording and that the speakers' voices are identified: R v Travers (1957) 58 SR (NSW) 85; 74 WN (NSW) 484; Walters Motors Pty Ltd v Cratchley [1964] NSWR 1085 . The original tape recording is admissible if it satisfies these requirements, but it is uncertain whether copies or re-recordings are also admissible: see generally R v Stevenson [1971] 1 All ER 278; R v Robson [1972] 2 All ER 699 ; cf R v Matthews [1972] VR 3 at 12 . Where, however, there is no dispute as to the accuracy of the transcript the most convenient course is for both parties to consent to its admission into evidence: Conwell v Tapfield [1981] 1 NSWLR 595 ; R v Maqsud Ali [1975] 2 All ER 464. See also Australian National Airlines Commission v Commonwealth (1975) 132 CLR 582; 6 ALR 433 . The combined effect of s 48(1) Evidence Act in light of R v Menzies [1982] 1 NZLR 40 ; Butera v DPP (Vic) (1987) 164 CLR 180; 76 ALR 45; BC8701825 and Eastman v R (1997) 76 FCR 9; 158 ALR 107; BC9702666 is: (a) A document that purports to be a transcript of words recorded on a tape is admissible to prove the conversation: s 48(1)(c); (b) No oral or other evidence is necessary to validate such a transcript, it being sufficient that it purports to be a transcript of the words: s 48(1)(c); (c) Where a tape is indistinct, a transcript may be used to assist the jury in the perception and understanding of what is recorded on the tape: Butera at (CLR) 187; (d) Where a tape is indistinct, a transcript made by an "ad hoc expert", being a person qualified only by having listened to the tape many times, may be used for this purpose. That is particularly so where the tape needs to be played over repeatedly before the words uttered could be made out unaided: Menzies at 49 cited in Butera at (CLR) 188; (e) If there is doubt or disagreement whether the transcript accurately deciphers the sounds captured on the tape, the transcript should be used only as an aide-memoire. The jury is to give priority to what they hear (or do not hear) on the tape, if that is not consistent with what appears in the transcript: Butera at (CLR) 188; (f) The jury may have the transcript before them when this tape is played over in court: Eastman at ALR 200; (g) The jury should be informed, when the transcript is tendered, as to the use which they may make of it: Eastman at FCR 220; (h) A transcript may be rejected or its use limited pursuant to ss 135–137: see R v Cassar [1999] NSWSC 436 ; BC9902633 (Sperling J) at [7]: see also R v Giovannone (2002) 140 A Crim R 1; [2002] NSWCCA 323; BC200204619 (Mason P) at [55]–[62]. The poor quality of a tape recording does not render it inadmissible per se, at least in circumstances where parts of it can be heard and deciphered. These matters will generally be matters of weight for the jury (R v Travers (1957) 58 SR (NSW) 85 at 98, 108–109; 74 WN (NSW) 484). The fact that a recording is indistinct or of poor quality has traditionally been the reason for the admission of a transcript into evidence (R v Dellapatrona (1993) 31 NSWLR 123 at 132 , Butera at (CLR) 187–8): R v Giovannone , above, at [51].

Evidence of a relevant practice may be given by a person who on a sufficient number of occasions and over a sufficient period has regularly and uniformly performed acts or has observed their performance by others under the same circumstances so as to make it appear probable that given the same circumstances and occasions the like acts will again be performed: Connor v Blacktown District Hospital [1971] 1 NSWLR 713 at 721 . Comprehended in this rule is that it is some evidence that a letter was posted if it can be seen that the ordinary practice of an office would have resulted in its despatch: Cotter v MacLean (1879) 13 Ch D 574 at 580 . Evidence of practice may be within the tendency rule and inadmissible unless notice is given: s 160 of the Evidence Act 1995. There is a presumption that a letter properly addressed and duly posted has reached the addressee: s 160 of the Evidence Act. See Smith Bros v Madden Bros [1945] QWN 33 (High Court): Watts v Vickers (1916) 86 LJKB 177; James v Twiss [1929] SASR 110 . Subject to any contrary contractual agreement, Australian postal articles will be presumed to have been delivered four days after posting: s 160 of the Evidence Act. As to the general law position in relation to the time of delivery in the ordinary course of post see Brady v Millgate [1965] NSWR 247; (1965) 82 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 282 and Bowman v Durham Holdings Pty Ltd (1973) 131 CLR 8 at 15; 2 ALR 193 . See also Hetherington v Kemp (1815) 171 ER 62 and Tanham v Nicholson (1872) LR 5 HL 561.

level.toc-caption: [29.5.45] Browne v Dunn — the rule in

heading.title: Browne v Dunn — the rule in

p.text: It is a fundamental rule of fairness in the conduct of litigation that, if the court is to be invited to disbelieve the evidence of a witness, or if the cross-examiner proposes to adduce contrary evidence, the particular issue must be put to the witness so that they have a fair opportunity to deal with the proposed justification for disbelief or contradiction: Browne v Dunn (1893) 6 R 67 ; Garrett v Nicholson (1999) 21 WAR 226 at 239, 247 ; Bulstrode v Trimble [1970] VR 840 at 846 ; Payless Superbarn (NSW) Pty Ltd v O'Gara (1990) 19 NSWLR 551 at 552, 555 and 560 ; R v Birks (1990) 19 NSWLR 677 at 688 . See also Precision Plastics Pty Ltd v Demir (1975) 132 CLR 362 at 370–1; 6 ALR 311; BC7500038 ; Allied Pastoral Holdings Pty Ltd v FCT [1983] 1 NSWLR 1; (1983) 44 ALR 607 at 623 . In relation to disbelief the justification for the rule is that the absence of relevant cross-examination can ordinarily be taken as implied acceptance of the witness's evidence: C v Minister of Community Welfare (1989) 52 SASR 304 ; Leydon v Tomlinson (1979) 22 SASR 302 at 306–7 ; Thomas v Van Den Yssel (1976) 14 SASR 205 at 207 . In the case of contradiction it is necessary to put to an opposing witness in cross-examination the nature of the case upon which it is proposed to rely, particularly where the contradiction relies upon inferences to be drawn from other evidence in the proceedings, so that the witness has a proper opportunity to “make any explanation open” to them; Allied Pastoral Holdings Pty Ltd v FCT [1983] 1 NSWLR 1 at 16; Karidis v GMH Pty Ltd [1971] SASR 422 at 425 ; See also R v Schneidas (1981) 6 A Crim R 101 at 107; Ghazal v GIO (NSW) (1992) 29 NSWLR 336 ; Glissan, “Putting or omitting to put questions in cross-examination” (1988) 62 ALJ 152; Martin v Rowling [2005] QCA 128 at [27] (failure to recall witness and cross-examine on inconsistencies derived from later oral evidence). This is particularly the case where the matter of proposed contradiction involves serious misconduct or fraud: R v Costi (1988) 48 SASR 269; Ghazal v GIO (1992) 29 NSWLR 336 . The requirement to give the witness a proper opportunity to address the challenge to their evidence does not require merely formulaic confrontation: Garrett v Nicholson (1999) 21 WAR 226 at 241, 247 ; Trade Practices Commission v Mobil Oil Australia Ltd (1984) 3 FCR 168 (witness disavowing any recollection of the relevant conversation). It is sufficient if the fact and nature of the challenge is otherwise apparent from the way in which the proceedings have been conducted: Herald & Weekly Times Ltd v Popovic (2003) 9 VR 1 at [367], [453] ; White Industries (Qld) Pty Ltd v Flower & Hart (a firm) (1998) 156 ALR 169; 29 ACSR 21; BC9803173 ; Flower & Hart (a firm) v White Industries (Qld) Pty Ltd (1999) 87 FCR 134 at 148; 163 ALR 744; [1999] FCA 773; BC9903036 ; Seymour v ABC (1990) 19 NSWLR 219; or if the evidence is patently incredible: Karidis v GMH Pty Ltd [1971] SASR 422 at 425 .

level.toc-caption: [29.5.50] Browne v Dunn — consequences of failure to comply with

p.text: Legislation cited in [29.5.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 135, s 136, s 46.

heading.title: Browne v Dunn — consequences of failure to comply with

p.text: There is no rule of law that a court is bound to accept uncontradicted evidence: see Re Doran Constructions Pty Ltd (in liq) (2002) 194 ALR 101; 168 FLR 116; [2002] NSWSC 215; BC200201196 and [29.5.110] . But a failure to cross-examine on a material aspect of a witness's evidence will usually imply acceptance of it: Ellis v Wallsend District Hospital (1989) 17 NSWLR 553 at 586 . Where the court is confronted with a breach of the rule in Browne v Dunn it has a wide discretion: R v Birks (1990) 19 NSWLR 677 at 688 . The exercise of the discretion will be influenced by factors such as the stage of the proceedings and the course of the trial. In particular, it may be significant to determine whether the failure to cross-examine has led to an assumption that the evidence was accepted. The circumstances of the particular case may show that such an assumption is unjustified. “Whether it is right to make such an assumption will depend upon, for example, whether counsel has at the time given adequate reason for not cross-examining the witness or otherwise made it clear that it is not a proper case in which to make that assumption ... It may be that the witness's evidence is fanciful or such as not to warrant cross-examination ... or that cross-examination is forgone for other adequate reasons, for example, delicacy; see Phipson on Evidence, 12th ed, Sweet & Maxwell, London, para 1543; Halsbury's Laws of England, 4th ed, vol 17, para 278. Similarly, failure to cross-examine a witness may not found such an assumption or render the course of the trial unfair if it is clear from the manner in which generally the case has been conducted that [their] evidence will be contested ... The nature of the defendant's case and the particulars given, and otherwise the conduct of it may make it sufficiently clear that such an assumption is unwarranted and that there has been no surprise or prejudice concerning the matter”: Seymour v Australian Broadcasting Commission (1977) 19 NSWLR 219 at 225 per Mahoney JA; see also Trade Practices Commission v Mobil Oil Australia Ltd (1984) 3 FCR 168 at 181; 55 ALR 527 ; Dolan v Australian & Overseas Telecommunications Corp (1993) 42 FCR 206; 114 ALR 231 at 236 . The party faced with a breach of the rule in Browne v Dunn may seek leave to recall the relevant witness: Evidence Act 1995 s 46 (see [50,360.15] ) — and such an application should normally be granted: MWJ v R (2005) 222 ALR 436; [2005] HCA 74; BC200510463 at [40] . The court may give directions about the use to which the contrary evidence is to be put: see Evidence Act 1995 s 136 . In exceptional cases the trial judge could prevent a party from calling evidence contrary to the rule: Payless Superbarn (NSW) Pty Ltd v O'Gara (1990) 19 NSWLR 551 at 552, 555 and 560 : see further Evidence Act 1995 ss 46 and 135 .

A burden of proof may be either evidentiary or persuasive. A persuasive burden lies upon a party who, when all the evidence is admitted, must satisfy the court, either on balance or beyond reasonable doubt, of the matters upon which it relies. This burden necessarily remains upon the same party throughout the proceedings: Purkess v Crittenden (1965) 114 CLR 164; [1966] ALR 98 ; Poricanin v Australian Consolidated Industries Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 419 ; (but where mitigation of damage is in issue see Munce v Vinidex Tube Makers Pty Ltd [1974] 2 NSWLR 235 ). An evidentiary burden on the other hand shifts according to the preponderance of the evidence at any particular point in time. Thus, where facts lie peculiarly within the knowledge of one party, very slight evidence by the party upon whom the persuasive burden lies may suffice to cast an evidentiary onus upon the other: Katsilis v Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd (1977) 18 ALR 181 at 197; 52 ALJR 189 ; De Gioia v Darling Island Stevedoring & Lighterage Co Ltd (1941) 42 SR (NSW) 1 at 7 ; Parker v Paton (1941) 41 SR (NSW) 237 at 243 . For the purpose of raising a prima facie case and thereby throwing upon the other party the onus of making an answer or giving an explanation, there is no distinction between civil and criminal proceedings: Wilson v Buttery [1926] SASR 150 .
Legislation cited in [29.5.60] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 103, 106.

There is a general, but not inflexible, rule that excludes evidence being led for the purpose of contradicting evidence that was given in cross-examination and which merely goes to the witness's credit. The true position is probably that the admissibility of such evidence is a matter for the discretion of the trial judge having regard to the issues in the case and the apparent relevance of the evidence sought to be led: Natta v Canham (1991) 32 FCR 282; 104 ALR 143 . The admissibility of all credit evidence is subject to Evidence Act 1995 ss 103 and 106 .
Legislation cited in [29.5.65] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

The credibility rule prevents cross-examination on credit unless the court is satisfied that the evidence could “substantially affect the assessment of the credibility of the witness”: Evidence Act 1995 s 103 . The witness's prior conduct or circumstances cannot be used to attack their credit unless it tends rationally and logically to weaken confidence in their veracity: Bickel v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 474 at 494 ; Wentworth v Rogers (No 10) (1987) 8 NSWLR 398 . In the latter case, cross-examination of a witness about their complaints of perjury by another witness was held to be improper. Furthermore, the court has a discretion to disallow embarrassing or unnecessary questions: Evidence Act 1995 s 41 . Except where Evidence Act 1995 s 106 applies, a witness's answer to questions that go only to credit may not be contradicted by affirmative evidence. Witnesses may be cross-examined about previous inconsistent statements, and on documents generally, in accordance with Evidence Act 1995 ss 43 , 44 , 63 and 64 .
Legislation cited in [29.5.70] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 40–42.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 35.2.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 56, 62(3)(a).

The extent to which cross-examination should be allowed in civil proceedings is a matter for the discretion of the court: Wentworth v Rogers (NSWSC, Sperling J, 28 April 1995, unreported, BC9507335) citing Banque Financiere de la Cite SA v Skandia (UK) Insurance Co Ltd [1991] 2 AC 249 at 280 and Ashmore v Corp of Lloyds [1992] 2 All ER 485; [1992] 1 WLR 446 at 453 ; but a witness is ordinarily liable to be cross-examined by the opposing party: see Evidence Act 1995 ss 40–42 . Generally the entitlement of the opposing party to cross-examine is an important consideration in ensuring the procedural fairness of the trial process. Thus, even where the witness's evidence in chief is to be given by affidavit rather than orally, the opposing party may require the deponent to attend court for the purpose of being cross-examined: see r 35.2 .

Cross-examination is not limited to the matters in respect of which the witness gave evidence in chief. In particular, the witness may be cross-examined on any relevant matter and any matter that goes to his or her credit: Wren v Emmett Contractors Pty Ltd (1969) 43 ALJR 213 at 221 . The court may place limitations on cross-examination to facilitate the determination of the real issues in dispute: CPA ss 56 and 62(3)(a) .
Legislation cited in [29.5.75] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 32, 34, s 37(1), ss 63, 64, 66A, s 78, s 80.

Where an ordinary witness is being examined in chief leading questions are not admissible without leave. This is so unless: (i) the question relates to an introductory or uncontentious matter; (ii) the witness is an expert and the question relates to the factual bases upon which the expert's opinion is based; (iii) the question relates to an investigation, inspection or report that the witness made in the course of carrying out public or official duties: Evidence Act 1995 s 37(1) and (2). Leading questions are those that either suggest to the witness the desired answer, or assume the existence of matters in dispute: Evidence Act 1995 s 37(1) and the Dictionary; J F Stephen, Digest of the Law of Evidence, Rothman, 1991, 6th ed at 146. In determining whether a question is leading it cannot be taken in isolation and, if a question does no more than fairly summarise the effect of evidence that has already been given, it cannot be regarded as leading. Nor is it leading if the question merely directs the attention of the witness to the subject matter about which he or she is to be questioned: GPI Leisure Corp Ltd v Herdsman Investments Pty Ltd (No 3) (1990) 20 NSWLR 15 . Moreover, the court has a discretion to admit leading questions in the interests of justice: Gordon v Carroll (1974) 6 ALR 579; 27 FLR 129; R v Thynne [1977] VR 98 at 101–3 : Evidence Act 1995 s 37(1)(a). For example, it may be permissible to put to a witness depositions that he or she gave at an earlier trial: Ex parte Bottomley [1909] 2 KB 14 at 21 .

Witnesses will generally be confined to matters within their own knowledge. But a witness can give evidence of matters of “first hand hearsay” (see Evidence Act 1995 ss 63 , 64 , 66A ), “lay opinions” (Evidence Act 1995 s 78 ) and matters of “common knowledge”: Evidence Act 1995 s 80 . Witnesses will be permitted, subject to certain limitations, to revive memory both before and while giving evidence: Evidence Act 1995 ss 32 and 34 . The documents used to refresh memory should have been written, or approved, by the witness and ought to have been made when the relevant events were fresh in memory: Evidence Act 1995 s 32; R v Simmonds [1967] 3 All ER 399; R v Richardson [1971] 2 QB 484 at 490 ; R v Van Beelen (1972) 4 SASR 594. Where documents are used to refresh memory in court they must be produced if required: Beech v Jones (1848) 5 CB 696 ; R v Naidanovici [1962] NZLR 334 : see Evidence Act 1995 s 34 .

The use of interpreters is widely accepted. A witness is not entitled as of right to give his or her evidence through an interpreter: Evidence Act 1995 s 30; Dairy Farmers Co-op Milk Co Ltd v Acquilina (1963) 109 CLR 458; [1964] ALR 333 ; Adamopoulos v Olympic Airways SA (1991) 25 NSWLR 75 at 77 and 80 ; Filios v Morland (1963) 80 WN (NSW) 501 . “Where difficulties of understanding and communication exist, either in relation to witnesses or parties, the court has a discretion to permit the use of an interpreter whenever it appears necessary to do so to ensure that evidence is accurately and efficiently given, that the proceedings are conducted fairly and that litigants, in particular, understand what is taking place”: Gradidge v Grace Bros Pty Ltd (1988) 93 FLR 414 (interpreter translating exchange between the judge and counsel after the judge's direction to desist); R v Johnson (1986) 25 A Crim R 433; R v Lee Kun [1916] 1 KB 337; Estate of Fuller [1965] 1 WLR 1336. The exercise of this discretion may sometimes require overriding the expressed preference of a witness as to the language in which his or her evidence is to be given. But if a witness only has a limited ability to communicate accurately and effectively in English the fact that the occasional answer is given in English, without the intervention of the interpreter, would not, of itself justify the witness being deprived of the interpreter's assistance: Faraj v GIO (NSWCA, Clarke, Handley and Sheller JJA, 17 June 1996, unreported). Conversely, it may breach natural justice if exchanges of question and answer between the judge and counsel, take place without being translated to the witness: Sook Rye Son v Minister For Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (1999) 86 FCR 584; 161 ALR 612 . In the common law division, a person may not be permitted to act as the court's interpreter if he or she has interpreted for a party at a conference with solicitor or counsel.

level.toc-caption: [29.5.85] Absence of witnesses or evidence — Jones v Dunkel inferences

heading.title: Absence of witnesses or evidence — Jones v Dunkel inferences

p.text: The capacity of a party to lead evidence on a matter in issue is relevant in assessing the sufficiency of the evidence on that issue. The propriety of making any finding of primary fact, or drawing an inference from primary facts, will depend on the nature of the matter in issue, the evidence that bears upon it, and the capacity of a particular party to have adduced either affirmative or contradicting evidence in relation to it: Payne v Parker [1976] 1 NSWLR 191 at 200 and 201 . In applying this general principle, as exemplified in the following notes, it is important to appreciate that they neither alter the onus of proof nor require the acceptance of any particular evidence: CSG Ltd v Fuji Xerox Australia Pty Ltd [2011] NSWCA 335; BC201108750 at [81]–[82] : as to uncontradicted evidence see [29.5.110] .

heading.title: Absence of evidence may inhibit favourable findings

p.text: A party who bears the onus of proof on a particular issue may reduce the likelihood of obtaining favourable findings (either or primary fact or inference) if they fail to give relevant evidence, fail to call an available witness, or fail to adduce relevant evidence from a witness who is called: White Industries (Qld) Pty Ltd v Flower & Hart (a firm) (1998) 156 ALR 169; 29 ACSR 21; [1998] FCA 806; BC9803173 ; Commercial Union Assurance Co of Australia Ltd v Ferrcom Pty Ltd (1991) 22 NSWLR 389; 6 ANZ Ins Cas 61-042 ; Ho v Powell (2001) 51 NSWLR 572; [2001] NSWCA 168; BC200103028 ; Pratt v Hawkins (1991) 32 NSWLR 319 at 323; BC9101956 ; Ex parte Harper; Re Rosenfield [1964–5] NSWR 58 at 62. The propriety and likelihood of such a party obtaining a favourable finding will depend on the quality and content of the whole of the evidence, the nature of the disputed issue, and the particular circumstances concerning the unadduced evidence. Where, for example, the particular issue is substantially a matter of inference from primary facts (such as the fact of reliance in fraud, trade practices or negligent mis-statement litigation, a plaintiff’s failure to give direct evidence of reliance will not necessarily preclude such a finding being made: Huntsman Chemical Co Australia Ltd v International Pools Australia Pty Ltd (1995) 36 NSWLR 242; 125 FLR 151; (1995) ATPR 41-403; BC9504308 ; Dominelli Ford (Hurstville) Pty Ltd v Karmot Auto Spares Pty Ltd (1992) 38 FCR 471; 110 ALR 535; (1992) ATPR 41-198; BC9203796 . Similarly, a party is not necessarily required to give cumulative or repetitive evidence on the same point: Cubillo v Commonwealth (No 2) (2000) 103 FCR 1 at 120; 174 ALR 97; [2000] FCA 1084; BC200004514 .

heading.title: Unexplained absence of evidence may justify limited adverse inference

p.text: A party’s unexplained failure to call relevant evidence may facilitate adverse findings being made against them: Jones v Dunkel (1959) 101 CLR 298 at 308 , 312 , 320–1; [1959] ALR 367; (1959) 32 ALJR 395; BC5900240 ; Earl v Castlemaine District Community Hospital [1974] VR 722 . Such findings may be made with the assistance of a limited adverse inference. The precise nature of that inference is a matter of some differences of expression. In Jones v Dunkel (1959) 101 CLR 298; [1959] ALR 367; (1959) 32 ALJR 395; BC5900240 Kitto J said that the unexplained absence of evidence permitted a finding to be more confidently made, and at least permitted an inference that the uncalled evidence would not have assisted: 101 CLR at 308. Menzies J said the unexplained absence of evidence more readily permitted a finding for which there was an evidentiary basis: 101 CLR at 312. Windeyer J referred to the two situations where a party failed to adduce any relevant evidence (eg from a witness) and where a party “who is capable of testifying” failed to give relevant evidence: 101 CLR at 321. In the latter case the unexplained absence of testimonial evidence from the party “may lead rationally to an inference that his evidence would not help his case”. The different expressions in Jones v Dunkel have led to the view that it approves two distinct reasoning processes: (i) to infer that the unadduced evidence would not have assisted the relevant party, (ii) to more confidently make a finding, (for which there is an apparently sufficient evidentiary basis) that is adverse to the party concerned: Kuhl v Zurich Financial Services Australia Ltd (2011) 243 CLR 361; 276 ALR 375; [2011] HCA 11; BC201102644 at [63] per Heydon, Crennan and Bell JJ. Kuhl v Zurich concerned the first kind of reasoning. Jones v Dunkel primarily concerned the second.

Both kinds of reasoning may be applied not only against the party who failed to explain the absence of evidence, but also against other parties in the same interest: Galea v Bagtrans Pty Ltd [2010] NSWCA 350; BC201009849 at [2] per Allsop P.

Notwithstanding well established authority for use of the Jones v Dunkel reasoning, and its frequent forensic deployment, the real practical utility of an inference that unadduced evidence would not have assisted a party’s case eludes confident expression. There are three reasons for that difficulty. The first is that the unexplained absence of evidence does not permit a positive finding that the absent witness' evidence would actually have been contrary to the party's case: R v Buckland [1977] 2 NSWLR 452 at 458 ; Brandi v Mingot (1976) 12 ALR 551 at 559–60; 51 ALJR 207; BC7600113 ; Manly Council v Byrne [2004] NSWCA 123; BC200406879 at [51] . The second is that no inference is open (at least in the absence of proper notice and reasoned analysis) that a party deliberately (and thus dishonestly) refrained from adducing the evidence because they apprehended it was unfavourable to their case: Kuhl v Zurich Financial Services Australia Ltd (2011) 243 CLR 361; 276 ALR 375 ; [2011] HCA 11; BC201102644 at [63]–[77] . The third reason is that the proper ultimate finding must, in every case, depend on the actual evidence that has been adduced. If that evidence provides (or fails to provide) a sufficient basis for a particular finding the force of an inference that other unadduced evidence “would not have assisted” adds little to the proper evidentiary assessment. Consequently, this aspect of the Jones v Dunkel reasoning operates to influence an impressionistic assessment about the actual sufficiency of the evidence that has been adduced on the particular matter, or as to whether any relevant inference should fairly be drawn: State Bank of NSW v Brown (2001) 38 ACSR 715; 19 ACLC 1415; [2001] NSWCA 223; BC200103738 at [17]–[18] . This is consistent with the general principle referred to in the first part of the present note, and discussed at length in Payne v Parker [1976] 1 NSWLR 191 at 200 and 201 .

heading.title: Where absence of witness requires explanation

p.text: The permissibility of drawing the limited adverse inference from the “unexplained” absence of a witness critically depends on the witness being “available”— in the sense of the reasonableness of the expectation that the relevant party should have called them.

A witness’ evidence is not “unexplained” unless the opposing party has adduced evidence requiring contradiction: Schellenberg v Tunnel Holdings Pty Ltd (2000) 200 CLR 121 at 141–3; 170 ALR 594; BC200001743 . Nor can any adverse inference arise where the absent witness was equally available to both parties: Payne v Parker [1976] 1 NSWLR 191 at 197 per Hutley JA and at 202 per Glass JA. In determining whether the witness was available to a party, the court is entitled to take into account both the power of the respective parties to call the witness and the reasonableness of their failure to do so (having regard, for example, to the association between the prospective witness and the opposing party): Ghazal v GIO (NSW) (1992) 29 NSWLR 336 ; Commercial Union Workers' Compensation NSW Ltd v Smith (NSWCA, Kirby, Priestley and Meagher JJA, 19 May 1994, unreported, BC9402718); Apollo Shower Screens Pty Ltd v Building & Construction Industry Long Service Payments Corp (1985) 1 NSWLR 561 at 565 ; Hospitality Group Pty Ltd v Australian Rugby Union Ltd (2001) 110 FCR 157; [2001] FCA 1040; BC200104902 at [64] ; Shum Yip Properties Developments Ltd v Chatswood Investment and Development Co Pty Ltd (2002) 166 FLR 451; 40 ACSR 619; BC200200582 (no inference where witness' employment ended long before proceedings); Fabre v Arenales (1992) 27 NSWLR 437; 15 MVR 303 (no inference where witness only available by subpoena); Cadwallader v Bajco Pty Ltd [2002] NSWCA 328; BC200205647 at [101] (inference available from unexplained failure to call a solicitor where privilege had been waived).

level.toc-caption: [29.5.87] Mere absence / destruction of evidence does not justify limited adverse inference

heading.title: Mere absence / destruction of evidence does not justify limited adverse inference

p.text: No adverse inference can arise from a mere absence of evidence: Hampton Court Ltd v Crooks (1957) 97 CLR 367 at 371; 64 ALR (CN) 1201; BC5700440 (the absence of contradictory evidence cannot remedy a deficiency in the case of the party that bears the ultimate onus of proof). The same limitation applies where the evidence is unavailable because it has been destroyed. The mere fact of destruction does not require any adverse inference to be drawn: Bridges v Pelly [2001] NSWCA 31; BC200100620 at [52] (absence of contemporaneous notes); Katsilis v Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd (1977) 18 ALR 181; BC7700106 (tool destroyed); British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd v Cowell (2003) 8 VR 571; [2003] VSCA 43; BC200301919 (documents destroyed before commencement of proceedings); Fuji Xerox Australia Pty Ltd v Lee [2003] QSC 303; BC200305342 (destruction of machine before commencement of proceedings). On the other hand, deliberate destruction of evidence for the purpose of precluding its use in the proceedings may justify not only an inference that the evidence would not have assisted the party’s case but also an inference of the party’s consciousness of the weakness of their case: Allen v Tobias (1958) 98 CLR 367 (destruction of executed agreement); The Ophelia [1916] 2 AC 206 at 229–30 (deliberate and unjustified destruction of documents); Marsden v Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd [2001] NSWSC 510; BC200103436 at [40] and [41]. Deliberate destruction of evidence after the commencement of proceedings may justify dismissal of the proceedings as an abuse of process: see [14.28.5] .

level.toc-caption: [29.5.90] Multiple counsel — examination in chief by

heading.title: Multiple counsel — examination in chief by

p.text: Where more than one counsel appear for a party, the leading counsel has the right to interpose during an examination in chief being taken by the junior and to continue the witness’ examination in chief: Doe v Roe (1809) 2 Camp 280 . Presumably it is also permissible for a leading counsel, after having commenced to lead evidence from a witness, to delegate part of the examination in chief to the junior.

Only one counsel for each party should be permitted to cross-examine a witness unless there are special circumstances justifying a departure from this established practice: Phillips v Phillips [1966] 1 NSWR 49; (1966) 83 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 445 ; GPI Leisure Corp Ltd v Herdsman Investments Pty Ltd (No 3) (1990) 20 NSWLR 15 . If the cross-examination is split between counsel it is proper to make it a condition of the leave to do so that there should be no overlap between the subject matter traversed by each cross-examiner: Eva Pty Ltd v Charles Davis Ltd [1982] VR 515 ; see also Lakatoi Universal Pty Ltd v Walker [1999] NSWSC 1088; BC9907447 (counsel unavailable to continue cross-examination).

The order in which witnesses give their evidence in chief is a matter for the party calling the witness: Briscoe v Briscoe [1968] P 501 . Judicial insistence on witnesses being called in a particular order; though generally erroneous, will not necessarily invalidate the proceedings: Barnes v BPC (Business Forms) Ltd [1976] 1 All ER 237; [1975] 1 WLR 1565 . Ordinarily witnesses will be cross-examined in the order in which they are called in chief but the court may permit the cross-examination of any witness to be deferred: GPI Leisure Corp Ltd v Herdsman Investments Pty Ltd (No 3) (1990) 20 NSWLR 15 .

Re-examination, like examination in chief and with the same exceptions, must be conducted without the use of leading questions. It is limited to matters “arising out of cross-examination”: see s 39 of the Evidence Act 1995. But this does not mean that re-examination is limited to removing ambiguities and uncertainties. It properly extends to eliciting from a witness any facts which explain or qualify matters which arose in the course of cross-examination and which are prejudicial to the witness's evidence or from which prejudicial inferences could be drawn: Roach v Page (t/as Freehill Hollingdale and Page) (No 2) [2003] NSWSC 772; BC200305949 ; R v Phair [1985] 1 Qd R 136 at 138; R v Lavery (No 2) (1979) 20 SASR 430 at 435, 451 ; Wodjcic v Incorporated Nominal Defendant [1969] VR 323 at 326 . In particular, if a witness has been cross-examined about part of a prior statement it may be proper in re-examination to prove any other parts of the statement which are necessary to explain or qualify the evidence given in cross-examination: Meredith v Innes (1931) 31 SR (NSW) 104 at 112; Wentworth v Rogers (No 10) (1987) 8 NSWLR 398 at 409 . It may also be permissible to re-examine about the witness’s state of mind at the time of giving particular cross-examination evidence: Drabsch v Switzerland General Insurance Co Ltd [1999] NSWSC 765; BC9904386 .

There is no rule of law that a court must accept uncontradicted evidence: Ellis v Wallsend District Hospital (1989) 17 NSWLR 553 at 586–8; (1989) Aust Torts Reports 80-289 ; Poricanin v Australian Consolidated Industries Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 419 ; Elkington v Shell Australia Ltd (1993) 32 NSWLR 11 at 17; 11 ACSR 583; 11 ACLC 942 ; McPhee v S Bennett Ltd (1934) 8 WCR 372; 52 WN (NSW) 8 at 9 ; Cole v Commonwealth (1962) 62 SR (NSW) 700 (jury's failure to wholly accept plaintiff's uncontradicted evidence not appealable as unreasonable); Levinge v Director of Custodial Services (1987) 9 NSWLR 546 at 560; 89 FLR 133; 27 A Crim R 163 . This is clearly the case where the witness's evidence is challenged in cross-examination, or where the witness is not accepted as credible: Tomic v Limro Pty Ltd (1993) 47 FCR 414 at 427; BC9305169 . A failure to cross-examine may imply acceptance of the evidence and justify a court in acting on it: Poricanin v Australian Consolidated Industries Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 419 at 426 : (but see R v Birks (1990) 19 NSWLR 677 at 690; BC9003813 ). But a court is not bound to accept evidence that was not the subject of cross-examination: Temiha v Sadebarth (NSWCA, Powell, Beazley and Stein JJA, 13 May 1997, unreported, BC9701895) (evidence of intention as to future conduct); Paric v John Holland Constructions Pty Ltd [1984] 2 NSWLR 505 at 507 ; Douglas v Tiernan (1931) 32 SR (NSW) 149 at 153; 49 WN (NSW) 31 ; Bulstrode v Trimble [1970] VR 840 at 849 .

Nevertheless, if a witness is accepted as credible, and the evidence is uncontradicted and neither inherently improbable nor unreasonable, it will generally be sufficient to satisfy a party's burden of proof: Holman v Holman [1964-5] NSWR 582; [1965] ALR 274; (1964) 5 FLR 406; 81 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 374 ; Repatriation Commission v Perrot (1984) 1 FCR 507; 53 ALR 690 at 707 . (This general proposition is related to the basic rule of fairness, that a party who proposes to contradict a witness, or invite the court to disbelieve their evidence, should give the witness a fair opportunity to deal with the proposed contradiction or justification for disbelief: see [29.5.45] dealing with the rule in Browne v Dunn (1893) 6 R 67 ; Garrett v Nicholson (1999) 21 WAR 226 at 239, 247; [1999] WASCA 32; BC9902790 ; Bulstrode v Trimble [1970] VR 840 at 846 .) The proposition applies to both lay and expert evidence: Hull v Thompson [2001] NSWCA 359; BC200106420 at [21]; State Rail Authority of NSW v Brown (2006) 66 NSWLR 540; [2006] NSWCA 220; BC200606050 .

The decided cases sometimes contain expressions to the effect that a court is bound to accept evidence uncontradicted and unchallenged: Precision Plastics Pty Ltd v Demir (1975) 132 CLR 362 at 371; 6 ALR 311; 49 ALJR 281; BC7500038 (plaintiff's evidence of disability) Hardy v Gillette [1976] VR 392 at 396 (opinion evidence about the nature of a substance); Repatriation Commission v Reid (1984) 54 ALR 157 at 162 . These expressions overstate the true position. It is open to an opposing party to submit, and for the court to find, that the evidence is inherently illogical or unreliable, or that it is substantially contradicted by other evidence: Nominal Defendant v Saleh (2011) 57 MVR 412; [2011] NSWCA 16; BC201102212 at [140]–[142]; Hamod v NSW [2011] NSWCA 375; BC201110561 at [336]–[340]. But, if uncontracted or unchallenged evidence is to be rejected, a court ought to deal specifically with the evidence in the judgment: Read v Nerey Nominees Pty Ltd [1979] VR 47 at 52 . This will require stating the specific reasons for the rejection of the evidence: Holman v Holman [1964-5] NSWR 582; [1965] ALR 274; (1964) 5 FLR 406; 81 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 374 .
For instances where uncontradicted evidence was not accepted see Taylor v Ellis [1956] VLR 457; [1956] ALR 1092 (failure to accept eye witnesses) and Re Gear [1964] Qd R 528 at 535 .

level.toc-caption: [29.5.115] Witnesses — discretion of the court to call

heading.title: Witnesses — discretion of the court to call

p.text: Numerous cases contain warnings about the undesirability of a judge becoming too actively involved in the conduct of the proceedings before him or her: Jones v National Coal Board [1957] 2 QB 55; [1957] 2 All ER 155 ; R v Apostilides (1984) 154 CLR 563; 53 ALR 445 . This understandable need for caution has led to some controversy as to the existence of a judge's power to call witnesses of his or her own motion. In particular, in Re Enoch and Zaretsky, Bock and Co's Arbitration [1910] 1 KB 327 Fletcher Moulton LJ and Farwell LJ expressed the view that a judge has no power to call a witness except with the consent of both parties. In so doing their Lordships expressly disagreed with an earlier observation of Lord Esher MR in Coulson v Disborough [1894] 2 QB 316 at 318 in which the Master of the Rolls appeared to accept the existence of such a power. Thereafter Enoch’s case has had a long life notwithstanding comments from time to time that the question is not really one of lack of power on the part of a judge to call witnesses but rather the need for extreme caution in the exercise of the power: R v Jenkins; Ex parte Morrison [1949] VLR 277 ; R v Collins [1907] VLR 292 . In criminal cases there was Australian authority for the view that a trial judge could not call a witness of his or her own motion except with the consent of the accused; Titheradge v R (1917) 24 CLR 107; 24 ALR 77 ; R v Evans [1964] VR 717 ; cf R v Cartledge [1959] VR 221 ; R v Picknell (1969) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 731 . On the other hand in England it had been held that in criminal matters a trial judge did have the power to call a witness if the interests of justice so required: R v Cleghorn [1967] 2 QB 584 ; R v Harris [1927] 2 KB 587 at 594 ; Archbold, Criminal Pleading, Evidence and Practice, 40th ed, 1979, para 592; Halsbury's Laws of England, 4th ed, Vol 11, para 296. Finally, the New South Wales Court of Criminal Appeal in R v Damic [1982] 2 NSWLR 750 and the High Court in R v Apostilides (1984) 154 CLR 563; 53 ALR 445 , while emphasising that a trial judge should call witnesses only in exceptional circumstances, rejected the view that he or she had no power to do so. Earlier in Bassett v Host [1982] 1 NSWLR 206 the New South Wales Court of Appeal had expressed the view that a trial judge should in an appropriate case exercise his or her influence to ensure that relevant witnesses were called. In Obacelo Pty Ltd v Taveraft Pty Ltd (1986) 10 FCR 518; 66 ALR 371 Wilcox J applied the reasoning in Damic , above, and Apostilides , above, to a civil trial and said that the decision in Enoch , above, should be regarded as an example of a miscarriage of the discretion to call a witness rather than as an authority against the existence of the trial judge's actual power to do so. The whole subject was thoroughly discussed by Sheppard J in a paper in (1982) 56 ALJ 234.

Witnesses who are to be called to give evidence may remain in court unless an order is made directing unexamined witnesses to leave the court until called: Evidence Act 1995 s 26(d); Tomlinson v Tomlinson [1980] 1 All ER 593 ; Southey v Nash (1837) 7 C & P 632. The power is discretionary: Holland v Evans [1959] VR 54 ; Moore v Registrar, Lambeth County Court [1969] 1 All ER 782; [1969] 1 WLR 141 per Edmund Davies LJ, “It cannot rightly be said that if witnesses are allowed to remain in court, justice cannot be done”. An order may be made at any stage of the proceedings: Southey v Nash , above; R v Cook (1696) 13 State Tr 311; Dickson v Malcolm (1853) 21 LTOS 199; but see Moffatt v Sutherland (1886) 2 QLJ 173. If a witness remains in court after such an order he or she may be punished for contempt but his or her evidence cannot be rejected: Cobbett v Hudson (1852) I El & Bl 11; 118 ER 341; Amos v Ruby Tin Mining Co (1873) 3 QSCR 173 ; R v Guttridge; Ex parte Campbell (1878) 4 VLR (E) 77 ; R v Briggs (1930) 22 Cr App R 68. A party to the cause is entitled to remain in court: London Chartered Bank v Lavers (1855) 2 Legge 884; Selfe v Isaacson (1858) 1 F & F 194; 175 ER 597; Dickson v Malcolm (1853) 21 LTOS 199 although in personal injury cases the plaintiff may leave the court when medical evidence called on his or her behalf is given before his or her testimony. Expert witnesses are generally permitted to remain in court — particularly where there is or may be a conflict of expert testimony. See also r 31.29 relating to the appointment of a court expert.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 29.6] r 29.6 Order of evidence and addresses (cf SCR Part 34, rule 6; DCR Part 26, rule 6; LCR Part 21, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Order of evidence and addresses (cf SCR Part 34, rule 6; DCR Part 26, rule 6; LCR Part 21, rule 4)

p.text: Subject to these rules and to any direction of the court:
if the only parties are one plaintiff and one defendant, and there is no statement of cross-claim or cross-summons, the order of evidence and addresses is to be as provided by this rule, and
in any other case, the order of evidence and addresses is to be as provided by this rule, subject to any modifications that the nature of the case requires.
The beginning party may make an address opening his or her case and may then adduce evidence.

If, at the conclusion of the beginning party’s evidence, no document or thing has been admitted in evidence on tender by the opposite party, the opposite party may elect to adduce evidence or not to adduce evidence.
If the opposite party elects to adduce evidence:
the opposite party may make an opening address before adducing evidence, and
after adducing evidence, the opposite party may make an address closing his or her case, and
after the close of the opposite party’s case, the beginning party may make an address closing his or her case.
If the opposite party elects not to adduce evidence:
the beginning party may make an address closing his or her case, and
after the close of the beginning party’s case, the opposite party may make an address stating his or her case.
Legislation cited in [29.6.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Rule 29.6(1).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 2.1, 2.3.

Rule 29.6(1) emphasises the court's general discretion to determine the appropriate procedure to be followed at the trial. Specific provisions which demonstrate the concern to achieve "the just, quick and cheap disposal of proceedings" (CPA s 56 ) are also found in the Rules (see UCPR rr 2.1 and 2.3 ) and in the Practice Directions. These specific provisions, however, should not be regarded as marking the limits of the judicial discretion to adopt appropriate trial procedures according to the circumstances of individual cases. In particular, where the trial is before a judge alone it is to be expected that the bench will take a more active role than if the trial was before a jury and perhaps more so than might have been the case in former times (for example, EI Du Pont de Nemours & Co v Cmr of Patents (1987) 16 FCR 423; 83 ALR 499 , and see also (1986) 2 Aust Bar Rev 260) although the judge must still avoid "descending into the arena"; Yuill v Yuill [1945] P 15; [1945] 1 All ER 183 ; R v Butler (1953) 53 SR (NSW) 330 at 331; Tousek v Bernat (1959) 61 SR (NSW) 203; 77 WN (NSW) 838 at 842. Other illustrations of the court's discretion and its power to ensure the proper conduct of proceedings occur where, for example, impropriety or incompetence becomes manifest during the course of the hearing. If a judge comes to the view that the material before them is fictitious or collusive they may refuse to proceed further. If the judge is of the view that the material evidence is incomplete or the case is otherwise inadequately prepared they may adjourn and give appropriate directions as to the further conduct of the proceedings: Deutsche Bank v Banque des Marchands de Moscou (1931) 107 LJKB 386 at 389; Morgan v Morgan (1982) FLC ¶91-225; Australasian Performing Rights Assn v Edmonds (NSWSC, Young J, 16 June 1987, unreported).

Counsel is not bound by everything said in the opening address unless they specifically limit their case to a narrow issue or issues and undertake not to rely upon others: Mummery v Irvings Pty Ltd (1956) 96 CLR 99 at 110–11; [1956] ALR 795 ; Doonan v Beacham (1953) 87 CLR 346; [1953] ALR 617 ; Valeriani v Gibson [1963] NSWR 1430 at 1435 . “The object of the opening address is to give a general notion of what will be given in evidence. Counsel in opening states the facts of the case, the substance of the evidence he or she has to adduce and its effect on proving his or her case, and remarks upon any point of law involved.”: Halsbury's Laws of England, 3rd ed, Vol 3, p 69.

Reference should not be made in addresses to matters which are not supported by any evidence which it is proposed to call or which has already been given: Tringali v Stewardson Stubbs & Collett Pty Ltd [1966] 1 NSWR 354 at 362; (1966) 66 SR (NSW) 335 ; Taylor v Edwards [1967] 1 NSWR 689; Vozza v Tooth & Co Ltd [1963] NSWR 1675 . In personal injury cases no reference should be made to the amount claimed by the plaintiff: Fairbairn v Cummins [1961] ALR 205 ; Pastoral Finance Assn v Minister (1913) 13 SR (NSW) 179; 30 WN (NSW) 43 ; Schofield v Wiggins (1957) 74 WN (NSW) 206 . If in a jury trial, improper reference is made to any matter this may justify a new trial but any such reference must be complained of at the earliest opportunity so that appropriate directions may be given: Vozza v Tooth & Co Ltd (1965) 112 CLR 316; [1965] ALR 196 ; Fitzpatrick v Walter E Cooper (1935) 54 CLR 200 at 210 ; Coniglio v Compressed Yeast Co (NSW) Pty Ltd [1964] NSWR 667 at 676 .

Where defendants are separately represented and all the defendants adduce evidence, the normal order of addresses at common law is that counsel for the first defendant on the record speaks first and is followed by counsel for the second defendant: Jeffree v Jeffree (1910) 54 Sol Jo 655; Hole v Robinson Bros & Co Ltd [1956] VLR 13 . Where only one co-defendant calls evidence the other co-defendant will retain the right to make the final address unless it is apparent from the way the case has been conducted that the defences are the same and the defendants are acting in concert in their conduct of the case: Powell v Begg (1898) 9 QLJ 110; Bickford v Bickford [1922] SASR 314 ; Roth v Roth (1928) 45 WN (NSW) 133 . In equity, the plaintiff almost always addresses first.

The fundamental principle to be applied in determining whether to grant an application for leave to reopen is whether the interests of justice are better served by allowing or rejecting the applications: Urban Transport Authority of New South Wales v Nweiser (1991) 28 NSWLR 471..

If the application for leave to reopen is made before the other party's case has commenced, leave should in general be granted (Henning v Lynch [1974] 2 NSWLR 254 ; Brown v Petranker (1991) 22 NSWLR 717; (1992) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-088 ), The same position probably applies if the application to reopen is made before, and perhaps even after, the hearing has been concluded: Smith v New South Wales Bar Assn (No 2) (1992) 176 CLR 256 at 266–7; 108 ALR 55 at 61 ; Gaskin v Ollerenshaw [2010] NSWSC 788; BC201005279 (evidence of conversation — recalled after trial — leave to reopen whilst judgment reserved — application allowed).

If the application is made after delivery of reasons for judgment different considerations apply: In Re Scott & Alvarez Contract [1895] 1 Ch 596 (application should generally be based on material not previously available); and see [36.16.45] and [36.16.50].

If the application to reopen is to call evidence which was not called earlier because of a deliberate tactical decision, that factor will ordinarily, but not necessarily always, may be relevant, but not necessarily be decisive against the application being granted: Smith v New South Wales Bar Assn (No 2) (1992) 176 CLR 256 at 266; 108 ALR 55 citing Hughes v Hill [1937] SASR 285 at 287 , to be taken into account: Urban Transport Authority of New South Wales v Nweiser , above; Joyce v GIO (NSW) (NSWSC, Sheppard J, 21 July 1976, unreported); Multicon Engineering Pty Ltd v Federal Airports Corp (NSWSC, Cole J, 10 December 1993, unreported, BC9302281)

In Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich [2006] NSWSC 826; BC200606432 at [18] Austin J set out a list of factors relevant to the exercise of the court’s discretion to permit a beginning party in a civil penalty proceeding to adduce further evidence after it had closed its case:
the nature of the proceeding;
whether the occasion for calling the further evidence ought reasonably to have been foreseen;

the consideration of fairness that the defendant is entitled to know all of the evidence he has to meet in taking forensic decisions as to cross-examination and the nature and extent of the evidence he will himself adduce on the matters in question;
the extent to which the plaintiff has embarked upon calling evidence on the issue in question in its case-in-chief;
the importance of the issue on which the further evidence is sought to be adduced to the pleaded issues in the case;
the degree of relevance and probative value of the further evidence sought to be adduced and its potential to involve an undue waste of time;
the prejudice to the defendant in terms of delay in the completion of the proceeding and the consequential costs;
the public interest in the timely conclusion of litigation;
what explanation is offered by the plaintiff for not having called the evidence-in-chief.
Legislation cited in [29.6.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 (r 29.6(4)(c).

A beginning party may have, in addition to the right to an address in reply (r 29.6(4)(c) , a right to call evidence in reply. There is no express provision for evidence in reply, but it is established by case law that the court has a discretion to permit it. As a matter of practice the plaintiff will usually serve any affidavits in reply before the commencement of the hearing, pursuant to the directions of the court designed to avoid surprise and ensure that the hearing is conducted fairly and efficiently. Where that party has been misled or taken by surprise in respect of matters contained in the other party's case the court may permit them to introduce supplementary or confirmatory evidence in reply: Barker v Furlong [1891] 2 Ch 172; Bigsby v Dickinson (1877) 4 Ch D 24. However, the general rule is that evidence in reply must be confined to evidence which rebuts the other party's case: Gilbert v Comedy Co (1880) 16 Ch D 594 ; Jacobs v Tarleton (1848) 11 QB 421 ; Green v Sevin (1879) 13 Ch D 589 . The mere fact that a defendant fails or refuses to call a witness does not give the plaintiff the right to call the witness in reply: Barker v Furlong, above.

Ordinarily, a plaintiff must lead in their case in chief all the evidence upon which they intend to rely. A plaintiff cannot "split" the case by reserving for reply evidence which should have been called in chief: Gilbert v Comedy Opera Co (1880) 16 Ch D 594 ; Re HIH Insurance Ltd (in prov liq): Australian Securities and Investment Commission v Adler (2001) 40 ACSR 214; BC200107887 . Nevertheless, there is authority for the view that, where there are several issues in dispute and in relation to some of them the burden is upon the defendant, a plaintiff may confine their evidence in chief to those issues in relation to which they bear the onus of proof: Shaw v Beck (1853) 8 Exch 392 at 398; 155 ER 1401 at 1403; Penn v Jack (1853) LR 2 Eq 314; Re Hardiman [1967] VR 577 at 580 . Whether these authorities establish an automatic entitlement in favour of a plaintiff in such a case to reserve evidence for a case in reply may be doubted: Beevis v Dawson [1957] 1 QB 195 at 204. But there is nevertheless power to permit a plaintiff, in an appropriate case, to split its case by reserving evidence on some issues until after the conclusion of the defendant's case. The best known instance of the exercise of this discretion is in relation to defamation cases and a defendant's plea of justification (Beevis v Dawson [1957] 1 QB 195; Browne v Murray (1825) Ry & M 254; 171 ER 1012; Jerome v Anderson (1964) 44 DLR (2d) 516 at 526 and 531 ) but, the appropriate exercise of the discretion is not limited to such cases: Protean (Holdings) Ltd v American Home Assurance Co [1985] VR 187 . However, once a plaintiff embarks upon the calling of evidence in relation to an issue they cannot thereafter seek to call further evidence in reply. This limitation applies even though the issue is one upon which the plaintiff does not bear the onus and in relation to which, consistent with the discretion referred to above, they could have sought leave to reserve a case in reply: Browne v Murray, above.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 29.7] r 29.7 Procedure to be followed if party is absent (cf SCR Part 5, rule 9, Part 13, rule 5A, Part 34, rule 5; DCR Part 26, rule 5A; LCR Part 21, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Procedure to be followed if party is absent (cf SCR Part 5, rule 9, Part 13, rule 5A, Part 34, rule 5; DCR Part 26, rule 5A; LCR Part 21, rule 2)

p.text: This rule applies when a trial is called on.
If any party is absent, the court:
may proceed with the trial generally or so far as concerns any claim for relief in the proceedings, or
may adjourn the trial.
If, in relation to a liquidated claim, the plaintiff appears, but a defendant does not appear, the court may, without proceeding to trial, give judgment against that defendant on evidence of:
the amount then due to the plaintiff in respect of the cause of action for which the proceedings were commenced, and
any payments made or credits accrued since the commencement of the proceedings in reduction of the amount of the plaintiff’s claim or costs.
If, in relation to any proceedings, the defendant appears, but the plaintiff does not appear, the court may dismiss the proceedings.
Subrules (3) and (4) do not limit the court’s powers under subrule (2).
[r 7 subst Amendment 4 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[7], effective 11 November 2005]

A party is relevantly absent only if they had knowledge, or notice, of the hearing date and are neither neither present nor represented when the matter is due to be heard: NSW Trustee & Guardian as Executor of the Will of Michael Robert Walsh (dec’d) v Gregory [2012] NSWSC 681; BC201204379 (all reasonable attempts had been made to notify the defendant). A party fails to appear, for the purpose of the present rule, if they have adequate notice of the hearing, and fail either to attend or provide the court with an apparently credible explanation for their non-attendance: Magjarraj v Asteron Life Ltd [2009] NSWSC 1433; BC200911502 at [22] (inadmissible doctor’s certificate asserting incapacity resulting from an undisclosed medical condition).

The primary considerations in determining whether to proceed in the absence of a party are (i) whether the party has been provided with due notice of the hearing, (ii) the nature of any explanation for party’s absence, (iii) the apparent urgency of the matter, (iv) the nature and extent of any hardship the ex parte order may cause, and (v) whether such an order can be set aside: Smirski v Macander [2010] NSWSC 929; BC201006065 at [34] ; Ndjamba v Toyota Finance Australia Ltd [2010] NTSC 23; BC201003140 at [8] (authority to make ex parte decision upheld).

If the defendant fails to appear, the plaintiff may prove their claim so far as the burden of proof lies upon them. The proof will be limited to the matters pleaded: Barker v Furlong [1891] 2 Ch 172 but once having proved the case the plaintiff is entitled to the relief claimed and such other relief as is consistent therewith: Stone v Smith (1887) 35 Ch D 188 and see Kingdon v Kirk (1887) 37 Ch D 141 . Although there may be admissions by a defendant by default in pleading (see r 14.2 and Termijtelen v Van Arkel [1974] 1 NSWLR 525) the grant of equitable relief is discretionary and the court will not do so in an undefended case if it is apparent that the plaintiff's case is hopelessly flawed: Bridge Wholesale Acceptance Corp (Aust) Ltd v Burnard (NSWSC, Young J, No 2140/91, 31 May 1991, unreported, BC9101944). If a joint defendant fails to appear damages may be apportioned between the defendants: Croston v Vaughan [1938] 1 KB 540 . If neither party appears the action will be struck out of the list subject to a right of restoration by order of a judge.
Legislation cited in [29.7.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 6.1 , 6.9.
