Although filing an appearance and defence are preconditions to being heard by the court (see UCPR rr 6.1 and 6.9 and de Pury v Briggs (1894) 15 ALT 272), the court should not allow a plaintiff to enter judgment against such a defendant when they are actually before the court, either personally or with legal representation: Redditch Benefit Building Society v Roberts [1940] Ch 415; [1940] 1 All ER 342 .

If the plaintiff fails to appear, the defendant is entitled to judgment dismissing the claim, and may proceed to prove any counterclaim that has been made. The effect of this judgment is the same as if it were a judgment dismissing the action on the merits: Armour v Bate [1891] 2 QB 223; Re Orrell Colliery & Fire Bricks Co (1879) 12 Ch D 681 at 682 ; Re South American & Mexican Co; Ex parte Bank of England [1895] 1 Ch 37 at 45; Crotty v Clarke (1895) 22 VLR 594 at 602; but see Kok Koong v Leong Cheong Kweng Mines [1964] AC 993; [1964] 1 All ER 300 .

The court has a discretion to refuse an application made under this rule to set aside a verdict or judgments but, as a general rule, the court will not set aside a judgment regularly obtained unless the defendant is able to show, prima facie, a good defence upon the merits: Rosing v Ben Shemesh [1960] VR 173 ; Vacuum Oil Pty Co Ltd v Stockdale (1942) 42 SR (NSW) 239 at 243 ; Evans v Bartlam [1937] AC 473 at 482; [1937] 2 All ER 646 ; Re Barraclough (dec'd) [1967] P 1; [1965] 2 All ER 311 ; but see Seymour v Holm [1961] Qd R 214 . Where judgment is set aside the party making the application will usually be required to pay the costs thereby thrown away: Burgoine v Taylor (1878) 9 Ch D 1; Cockle v Joyce (1877) 7 Ch D 56; Passmore v Minahan (1887) 13 VLR 262 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 29.8] r 29.8 Dismissal of proceedings on plaintiff’s application (cf SCR Part 34, rule 6A; DCR Part 26, rule 6A; LCR Part 21, rule 5(1))

leg:heading.title: Dismissal of proceedings on plaintiff’s application (cf SCR Part 34, rule 6A; DCR Part 26, rule 6A; LCR Part 21, rule 5(1))

p.text: On the application of the plaintiff in any proceedings, the court may make an order for the dismissal of the proceedings to the extent to which they concern:
the whole or any part of the plaintiff’s claim for relief, and
any cause of action relevant to that claim or part of the claim.
Subject to subrule (3), such an order may be made at any time.
In the case of a trial with a jury, such an order may be made only if the application for the order is made before the jury gives a verdict.
Legislation cited in [29.8.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 12.10, r 12.2, r 42.20.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 91.

Previously a party could not discontinue a claim once the hearing has commenced (SCR Pt 21 r 2, by a 1985 amendment, provided that once the trial had commenced no discontinuance, by leave or otherwise, was permissible and the action could be disposed of only by judgment: Flick v Nash (NSWCA, Samuels JA, CA 518/1986, 9 February 1987, BC8701600), but see now UCPR r 12.2 . A party who does not wish to pursue a claim after the commencement of the hearing, will not generally be compelled to pursue the claim: Ritz Hotel Ltd v Charles of the Ritz Ltd (No 8) (1987) 12 IPR 75 at 76–77 . Subject to any terms imposed, a dismissal (not involving a hearing on the merits) does not prevent a party from recommencing fresh proceedings on the claim: CPA s 91 . A party who successfully applies for dismissal will ordinarily be required to pay the costs of the other party (see UCPR r 42.20 ), unless there is a basis to displace the general rule: Kiama City Council v McMillan [2003] NSWCA 33; BC200301128 at [65]–[66] . If the costs are not paid prior to commencement of fresh proceedings, the defendant may apply to stay the new proceedings: r 12.10 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 29.9] r 29.9 Dismissal of proceedings on defendant’s application (cf SCR Part 34, rule 7; DCR Part 26, rule 7; LCR Part 21, rule 5(2)–(7))

leg:heading.title: Dismissal of proceedings on defendant’s application (cf SCR Part 34, rule 7; DCR Part 26, rule 7; LCR Part 21, rule 5(2)–(7))

p.text: A defendant in proceedings in which the plaintiff is the beginning party may apply to the court for an order:
for the dismissal of the proceedings, or
for the dismissal of the proceedings to the extent to which they concern any cause of action relevant to the plaintiff’s claim for relief against that defendant,
on the ground that, on the evidence given, a judgment for the plaintiff could not be supported.
Such an application may be made at any time after the conclusion of the evidence for the plaintiff in his or her case in chief.
The plaintiff may argue, or decline to argue, the question raised by the application.

The court may not make an order under this rule unless the plaintiff argues the question raised by the application and the defendant satisfies the court that, on the evidence given, a judgment for the plaintiff could not be supported.

If the plaintiff declines to argue the question raised by the application, or if the defendant fails to satisfy the court that, on the evidence given, a judgment for the plaintiff could not be supported, the defendant:
may adduce evidence or further evidence, or
may make an application under rule 29.10 .
If fewer than all defendants apply to the court under subrule (1), the court must not deal with any such application before the conclusion of the evidence given for all parties.
Legislation cited in [29.9.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 91.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 12.2.

A dismissal order under the present rule does not prevent a plaintiff bringing new proceedings: CPA s 91 . In this respect the rule is similar to the effect of a nonsuit in the pre Judicature Act procedures. Both at common law and in equity a plaintiff could withdraw at any time without losing the right to bring new proceedings: Fox v Star Newspaper Co Ltd [1898] 1 QB 636; [1900] AC 19 ; Phillips v Ellinson Bros Pty Ltd (1941) 65 CLR 221 at 228; [1941] ALR 340 ; Clack v Arthur’s Engineering Ltd [1959] 2 QB 211; [1959] 2 All ER 503 ; Blackmore v Flexhide Pty Ltd [1979] 1 NSWLR 103 but see Vacic v Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd [1982] ACLD 680. That ability is restricted by r 12.2 which, in the absence of consent, prevents a plaintiff from discontinuing, without leave of the court. The present rule provides for a modified “nonsuit” procedure under which proceedings may be dismissed on the defendant’s application without preventing new proceedings being brought: Tamsett v Conditionaire Engineering Pty Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 511 ; Humphrey v Collier [1946] VLR 391 at 404 ; and see Schipp v Herfords Pty Ltd [1975] 1 NSWLR 412 at 423 and Fox v Star Newspaper Co Ltd [1898] 1 QB 636; [1900] AC 19 .
Legislation cited in [29.9.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 29.10.

Consistent with the earlier nonsuit procedures, a dismissal order cannot be made under the present rule if the plaintiff refuses to argue the question: Tate v Johnson (1953) 53 SR (NSW) 492 at 494–5 ; Peat v Irvine (1910) 27 WN (NSW) 121 ; but see Jones v Dunkel (1959) 101 CLR 298 at 329; [1959] ALR 367 (consent to nonsuit); Dashborough v Perpetual Trustee Co (1896) 13 WN (NSW) 92 (consent implied when point argued by plaintiff). But if the plaintiff refuses to argue the nonsuit point, the defendant can still move for judgment under r 29.10 . Under that rule, however, the defendant will be put to an election about calling further evidence.
Legislation cited in [29.9.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 108.

A “nonsuit” is proper if a verdict could not reasonably be given for the plaintiff on the evidence adduced: Hiddle v National Fire & Marine Insurance Co of New Zealand [1896] AC 372 at 375–6 ; De Gioia v Darling Island Stevedoring & Lighterage Co Ltd (1941) 42 SR (NSW) 1 ; Jones v Dunkel (1959) 101 CLR 298 at 330–1; [1959] ALR 367 (nonsuit procedure in non-jury trials). If the evidence is equivocal about the existence or non-existence of a fact that the plaintiff must establish, the case must fail and a dismissal order is appropriate: Bell v Thompson (1934) 34 SR (NSW) 436; Carr v Baker (1936) 36 SR (NSW) 301 . In theory, a judge may order a nonsuit even where the defendant makes no application: Banbury v Bank of Montreal [1918] AC 626 ; see also De Gioia's case, but the practice is to the contrary: Jones v Dunkel, above,CLR at 328 . A dismissal order may be made on appeal: s 108 of the Supreme Court Act; Hocking v Bell (1945) 71 CLR 430 at 466; 46 SR (NSW) 251 ; Shepherd v Felt & Textiles of Australia Ltd (1931) 45 CLR 359 at 379; 37 ALR 194 ; but it will only be appropriate to do so if on the whole of the evidence, including that given by the defendant, a judgment for the plaintiff is not reasonably open: Ostermeyer v Harrold (1895) 12 WN (NSW) 38.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 29.10] r 29.10 Judgment for want of evidence (cf SCR Part 34, rule 8; DCR Part 26, rule 8; LCR Part 21, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Judgment for want of evidence (cf SCR Part 34, rule 8; DCR Part 26, rule 8; LCR Part 21, rule 6)

p.text: An opposite party may apply to the court to give judgment for the opposite party, either generally or on any claim for relief in the proceedings, on the ground that, on the evidence given, a judgment for the beginning party could not be supported.
Such an application may be made at any time after the conclusion of the evidence for the beginning party in his or her case in chief.
The court may not give judgment under this rule unless the opposite party satisfies the court that, on the evidence given, a judgment for the beginning party could not be supported.

If the opposite party fails to satisfy the court that, on the evidence given, a judgment for the beginning party could not be supported, the opposite party may not adduce evidence or further evidence in the proceedings generally or on the claim for relief concerned, as the case may be, except by leave of the court.
If not all opposite parties apply to the court under subrule (1), the court must not deal with any such application before the conclusion of the evidence given for all parties.

level.toc-caption: [29.10.5] No case to answer — defendant ordinarily put to election

p.text: Legislation cited in [29.10.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 29.10(2), r 29.10(4).

heading.title: No case to answer — defendant ordinarily put to election

p.text: Apart from the present rule if a “no case” submission was made, the court had a discretion to put the defendant to an election about calling evidence before ruling on the no case submission: Rasomen Pty Ltd (t/as Shell Fairview Park) v Shell Co of Australia Ltd (1997) 75 FCR 216; 144 ALR 497 ; Humphrey v Collier [1946] VLR 391 ; Sampson v Edwards [1949] VLR 6 ; Protean (Holdings) Ltd v American Home Assurance Co [1985] VR 187 . Unless there was an objection to the jurisdiction of the court (Stevenson v Barham (1977) 136 CLR 190 at 202; 12 ALR 175 ), the court would ordinarily require the defendant to elect: Laurie v Raglan Co [1942] 1 KB 152 ; Alexander v Rayson [1936] 1 KB 169 at 178 ; Protean (Holdings) Ltd v American Home Assurance Co [1985] VR 187 — see also Tate v Johnson (1953) 53 SR (NSW) 492 and James v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (No 2) (1985) 9 FCR 448 where the authorities are thoroughly examined. Rule 29.10(4) adopts the ordinary common law rule and prevents further evidence being called by a defendant once an application has been made under r 29.10(2) and determined by the court: Builders Licensing Board v Mahoney (1986) 5 NSWLR 96 — unless, as r 29.10(4) now expressly permits, the court gives leave to the opposite party to adduce evidence.

A submission of no case to answer encompasses both evidence insufficient in law and also evidence so unsatisfactory that the court should not act upon it: Yuill v Yuill [1945] P 15; [1945] 1 All ER 183 ; Union Bank of Australia Ltd v Puddy [1949] VLR 242 at 244 . In dealing with a submission of no case to answer the question to be decided is whether there is any evidence that is reasonably capable of satisfying the tribunal of fact that the matters sought to be proved have been established: Ryder v Wombwell (1868) LR 4 Ex 32 at 39; Metropolitan Railway Co v Jackson (1877) 3 App Cas 193 at 207 ; Commissioner for Corporate Affairs v Green [1978] VR 505 at 513 ; Mailman v Ellison (NSWCA, Mahoney, Sheller JJA, 25 November 1993, unreported, BC9302273); approved in Hunt v Watkins (2000) 49 NSWLR 508; [2000] NSWCA 229; BC200005009 . This formulation suggests that the question is to be approached by taking the plaintiff’s evidence at its highest: Naxakis v Western General Hospital (1999) 197 CLR 269; 162 ALR 540 ; De Gioia v Darling Island Stevedoring & Lighterage Co Ltd (1941) 42 SR (NSW) 1 at 3 ; Waverley Municipal Council v Swain (2003) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-694; [2003] NSWCA 61; BC200301409 .

level.toc-caption: [29.10.15] No case to answer — multi party proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [29.10.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 29.1.

heading.title: No case to answer — multi party proceedings

p.text: Where proceedings involve multiple parties, and particularly where they include cross claims, the “beginning” and “opposite” parties for the purposes of UCPR r 29.1 are not identified solely by their formal status in relation to the formal claims and cross claims. Consequently, a cross defendant is not entitled to apply for judgment under the present rule merely upon the conclusion of the evidence-in-chief of the particular “beginning” party to the cross claim against them. The evidence-in-chief of all parties with an opposing interest in the proceedings must be concluded before any cross claimant may apply under the present rule: Khan (as trustee for the Khan Family Trust) v Hadid [2007] NSWSC 314 .
